revision.comment: Reverted edits by [[Special:Contribs/208.54.86.204|208.54.86.204]] ([[User talk:208.54.86.204|talk]]) to last version by KolbertBot
revision.text:
[[Image:Dr karp.jpg|thumb|Harvey Karp]]
'''Harvey Neil Karp''', [[American Academy of Pediatrics|FAAP]] (born 1951) is an American [[pediatrician]] and children’s environmental health advocate.<ref>{{cite web|title = Harvey Karp - Our Board of Directors {{!}} Healthy Child Healthy World|url = http://www.healthychild.org/about-us/dr-harvey-karp/|website = Healthy Child Healthy World|accessdate = 2015-10-09}}</ref> He is an Assistant Professor of Pediatrics at the [[Keck School of Medicine of USC|Keck School of Medicine at the University of Southern California]] and a fellow of the [[American Academy of Pediatrics]]. Karp lives in Los Angeles with his wife [[Nina Montée Karp|Nina Montee Karp]].<ref name="auto">{{cite web|title = January Guest Speaker: Dr. Harvey Karp (2013)|url = http://blogs.dctc.edu/dawnbraa/2013/01/01/january-guest-speaker-dr-harvey-karp-2013/|website = Early Childhood and Youth Development|accessdate = 2015-10-22}}</ref>
Karp is best known for his techniques for calming infants and promoting sleep. He is the author of a series of books and DVDs on parenting.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.scholastic.com/parents/resources/article/parent-child/10-most-influential-people-family-life-today-0|title=The 10 Most Influential People In Family Life Today|newspaper=Scholastic.com|access-date=2016-10-16}}</ref>
== Career == From 1982 to 1984 Karp practiced pediatrics with pediatrician [[Paul Fleiss]] in Los Angeles, California.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Gordon|first1=Jay|title=Remembering Dr. Paul Fleiss: 5 Decades in Pediatrics|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/jay-gordon/dr-paul-fleiss-5-decades-in-pediatrics_b_5604011.html|website=Huffington Post|accessdate=30 January 2016}}</ref> He then opened his own practice in Santa Monica, where he continued to see patients until 2005. He was assistant clinical professor of pediatrics at the UCLA School of Medicine<ref>{{cite web|title = The Baby Whisperer - UCLA Magazine|url = http://magazine.ucla.edu/exclusives/harvey_karp/|website = UCLA Magazine|accessdate = 2015-10-22}}</ref> from 1989 to 2009, where he served as pediatric liaison to the Child Abuse Team.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.seattlepi.com/lifestyle/health/article/Shhh-UCLA-pediatrician-develops-the-Cuddle-1092657.php|title=Shhh.... UCLA pediatrician develops the 'Cuddle Cure' to calm colicky infants|access-date=2016-09-14}}</ref> He appeared as a regular contributor to the Lifetime cable television show ''Growing Up Together'' from 1990 to 1992.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://productionbeast.com/projects/106947-growing-up-together|title=Growing Up Together|work=ProductionBeast}}</ref> In 2009, he became an assistant professor of pediatrics at the USC Keck School of Medicine.
Karp is a founding board member of Healthy Child Healthy World,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.ewg.org/about-us/board-members|title=Board Members|newspaper=EWG|access-date=2016-10-17}}</ref> and has served on the advisory boards of the Green Guide, Babycenter.com, ''Parents'', ''Ser Padres,'' and ''American Baby'' magazines.<ref name="auto" />
Most recently, Karp has collaborated with [[Yves Béhar]] to develop a "[[Smart objects|smart]]" [[bassinet]]. Karp claims that it is able to calm fussing babies.<ref name="Snoo cradle">{{cite news|last1=Rhodes|first1=Margaret|title=The $1,200 Snoo Robo-Cradle Will Rock Your Baby to Sleep For You|url=https://www.wired.com/2016/10/robo-cradle-will-rock-baby-sleep/|accessdate=19 February 2017|publisher=WIRED|date=18 October 2016}}</ref>
==Infant calming and sleep technique== Karp’s infant calming technique is supposed to be based on recreating the essential elements of the experience of living in the womb. Human babies, according to Karp, are born less developed than other mammals. Karp calls the first three months of life the "fourth trimester."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/2012/06/24/155426534/dr-karp-on-parenting-and-the-science-of-sleep|title=Dr. Karp On Parenting And The Science Of Sleep|last=|first=|date=|newspaper=National Public Radio|access-date=February 19, 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|work=|department=All Things Considered|via=}}</ref> Karp hypothesizes that all babies are born with a "calming reflex" that quickly relaxes most fussy babies when they are stimulated in a way that resemble sensations that babies experience in the womb.<ref>Karp H, The “fourth trimester”: A framework and strategy for understanding and resolving colic, Contemporary Peds 2001;21:92-114</ref> His method for soothing crying babies, the so-called 5 S's,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.today.com/parents/research-backs-power-5-ss-soothe-babies-717333|title=Research backs up the power of the 5 S's to soothe babies|last=TODAYMoms|access-date=2016-09-14}}</ref> includes [[swaddling]], side/stomach position, shushing, swinging and sucking.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/03/08/health/colicky-baby-read-this-before-calling-an-exorcist.html|title=Colicky Baby? Read This Before Calling an Exorcist|last=Blakeslee|first=Sandra|date=2005-03-08|newspaper=The New York Times|issn=0362-4331|access-date=2016-09-14}}</ref>
Regarding sleep, Karp recommends nightly swaddling and sound and motion sleep cues to help babies establish a circadian rhythm and to promote infant sleep.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/2012/06/24/155426534/dr-karp-on-parenting-and-the-science-of-sleep|title=Dr. Karp On Parenting And The Science Of Sleep|website=NPR.org|access-date=2016-09-14}}</ref>
==Criticism== CBS news reports that "Critics say Karp is riding to fame on the strength of his patients' VIP parents, who include [[Michelle Pfeiffer]], [[Pierce Brosnan]] and [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]]. Endorsements from several stars appear on his book jacket and video cover."<ref name="CBS">{{Citation |last = AP|date = 2002-10-21|title = Can This Man Keep Your Baby Quiet?|publisher = CBS News|url = http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2002/10/21/health/main526308.shtml|accessdate = 23 October 2008}}</ref>
Some doctors have also expressed concern that babies may accidentally be left to sleep face down, a position which increases the risk of [[sudden infant death syndrome]]. Karp explicitly warns parents not to leave babies in this position.<ref>{{Cite news | last=Falcon | first=Mike | last2=Shoop | first2=Stephen A. | date=2002-09-09 | title="Happy baby doctor" calms colic crying | publisher=USA Today | url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/health/spotlighthealth/2002-09-09-karp_x.htm | accessdate=23 October 2008}}</ref>
Ralph Frenken has argued against Karp’s recommendation of the use of tight [[swaddling]] and the concept of a "calming reflex." The criticism is that the effect of swaddling is not based on [[reflex]]es because (1) a releasing stimulus is missing, because swaddling most probably works by the decrease of proprioceptive and tactile stimulation and (2) the reflex response is missing, because any reflex always consists of a movement released by muscles.<ref>Frenken, Ralph (2011). Psychology and history of swaddling: Part two – The abolishment of swaddling from the 16th century until today. In: The Journal of Psychohistory, 39 (3), p. 219-245.</ref> The child does not move but falls asleep by swaddling. Additionally, no known reflex alters the state of consciousness, but swaddling obviously does. Lactation and breastfeeding expert, Nancy Mohrbacher, collected several scientific studies which demonstrated negative aspects of swaddling on newborn infants.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nancymohrbacher.com/articles/2010/12/3/rethinking-swaddling.html |title=Rethinking Swaddling — Nancy Mohrbacher |publisher=Nancymohrbacher.com |date=2010-12-03 |accessdate=2016-07-13}}</ref>
In 2010, researchers studied the effects of video instruction concerning swaddling, side positioning, white noise, jiggling, and sucking on parents' ability to calm fussing babies. The results against a control group were statistically insignificant compared to traditional methods.<ref>Jonna M. McRury, Adam J. Zolotor: A Randomized, Controlled Trial of a Behavioral Intervention to Reduce Crying among Infants. In: J Am Board Fam Med September 1, 2010 23:689-690.</ref> Other than that, no aspect of Karp's calming techniques concerning the psychological or physical consequences on babies has been discussed by the scientific community.
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2010}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Karp, Harvey}} [[Category:American pediatricians]] [[Category:American family and parenting writers]] [[Category:Babycare]] [[Category:University of California, Los Angeles faculty]] [[Category:Albert Einstein College of Medicine alumni]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1951 births]]

revision.comment: Updating occupation in into
revision.text:
{{Like resume|date=December 2008}} {{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = | name = Helen Greiner | honorific_suffix = | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | nationality = American | citizenship = | birth_name = | birth_date = December 6, 1967 | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | education = | spouse = | parents = | children = | module = {{ infobox engineering career | discipline = | institutions = | practice_name = | employer = iRobot,
CyPhyWorks | significant_projects = | significant_design = | significant_advance = | significant_awards = Anita Borg Institute Women of Vision Awards }} | signature = | signature_alt = }} '''Helen Greiner''' (born December 6, 1967) is a co-founder of [[iRobot]] and former CTO of CyPhyWorks,{{cite web|title=General Catalyst Partners page on Helen Greiner|date=Nov 5, 2010|url=http://www.generalcatalyst.com/entrepreneurs/helen-greiner}} a start-up company specializing in small multi-rotor drones for the consumer, commercial and military markets. ==Early life and education== Greiner was born in London in 1967. Her father came to England as a refugee from Hungary, and met his wife, Helen's mother, at the University of London. When Helen was 5, her family moved to Southampton, New York, USA.{{cite web|title=Helen Greiner Biography|url=http://www.notablebiographies.com/news/Ge-La/Greiner-Helen.html|publisher=Encyclopedia of World Biography|accessdate=3 April 2016}} At the age of ten Greiner went to see the popular film ''[[Star Wars (film)|Star Wars]]''. She has said she was inspired to work with robots by [[R2-D2]] in the film . Greiner graduated from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in 1989, and earned her Master's there (SM) in 1990.{{cite web|title=Helen Greiner: Filling the World with Robots|url=http://spectrum.mit.edu/continuum/helen-greiner-filling-the-world-with-robots/|publisher=Spectrum: Massachusetts Institute of Technology|accessdate=3 April 2016|date=23 January 2015}} ==Career== In 1990, along with [[Rodney Brooks]] and [[Colin Angle]], Greiner co-founded [[iRobot]], a robotics company headquartered in [[Bedford, Massachusetts]], which delivers robots into the consumer market. She co-designed the first version of the [[iRobot]] [[Roomba]].{{cite news |url=http://www.mercurynews.com/News/ci_27291310/Drone-market-resembles-Silicon-Valleys-early-days |first=Scott |last=Mayerowitz |title=Market resembles valley's early days |newspaper=[[San Jose Mercury News]] |agency=Associated Press |date=January 11, 2015 }} Greiner served as President of [[iRobot]] (NASDAQ: IRBT) until 2004 and Chairman until 2008. During her tenure, iRobot released the [[Roomba]], the [[PackBot]] and [[SUGV]] military robots. She built a culture of practical innovation and delivery that led to the deployment of 6,000 PackBots with the United States armed forces. In addition, Greiner headed up iRobot’s financing projects, raising $35M in venture capital for a $75M initial public offering.{{cite web|title=Helen Greiner|url=https://startmit.mit.edu/helen-greiner/|publisher=StartMIT|accessdate=3 April 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160416011727/https://startmit.mit.edu/helen-greiner/|archivedate=16 April 2016|df=}} She has worked at NASA's [[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]] and the [[MIT Artificial Intelligence Laboratory]].{{cite web|title=Helen Greiner|url=https://www.ncwit.org/profile/helen-greiner|website=NCWIT.ORG|publisher=National Center for Women and Information Technology|accessdate=3 April 2016}} Greiner was recently CTO of CyPhy Works, home to the Persistent Aerial Reconnaissance and Communications (PARC) and Pocket Flyer multi-rotor drones. She also served on the board of the Open Source Robotics Foundation (OSRF).{{cite web|title=Board of Directors, OSRF|date=Jan 28, 2013|url=https://web.archive.org/*/www.osrfoundation.org/people/#board}} As of 2018 she works as an advisor to the [[United States Army]]. {{cite web|url=https://www.americaninno.com/boston/inno-news-boston/cyphy-works-raises-4-5m-as-founder-helen-greiner-leaves-the-company/?mc_cid=cfdfb002c0&mc_eid=13449a09da|date= June 14, 2018| title=CyPhy Works Raises $4.5M as Founder Helen Greiner Leaves The Company }} ==Awards and recognition== In 2014, Greiner was named a Presidential Ambassador for Global Leadership (PAGE) by US President, [[Barack Obama]] and US Secretary of Commerce, [[Penny Pritzker]].{{cite web|last1=Zuberi|first1=Bilal|title=Proud of Helen Greiner, Presidential Ambassador for Global Entrepreneurship|url=https://medium.com/@lux_capital/proud-of-helen-greiner-presidential-ambassador-for-global-entrepreneurship-4b5b58b7510f|website=Medium|publisher=Medium|accessdate=1 May 2015}} She received the 2008 [[Anita Borg Institute Women of Vision Awards|Anita Borg Institute Women of Vision Award]] for Innovation for her work at [[iRobot]].{{cite web|title=Women of Vision awards presented at Anita Borg Institute banquet|url=http://www.diversitycareers.com/articles/pro/08-augsep/soc_news_ABI.htm|work=Diversity/Careers|publisher=Diversity/Careers|accessdate=29 June 2011|date=August–September 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110928005111/http://www.diversitycareers.com/articles/pro/08-augsep/soc_news_ABI.htm|archivedate=28 September 2011|df=}} She has also been honored as one of [[Technology Review]] Magazine's [[TR35|TR100]] "Innovators for the Next Century." In 2007, Greiner was inducted into the [[Women in Technology International]] Hall of Fame.{{cite web|title=WITI Hall of Fame Featured Profile|url=http://www.witi.com/center/witimuseum/halloffame/239374/Helen-Greiner-Co-founder-and-Chairman-iRobot-Corp/|website=WITI|publisher=Women in Technology International|accessdate=1 May 2015}} In 2006, she received the Pioneer Award from the [[Association for Unmanned Vehicle Systems International]](AUVSI).{{cite web|title=Unmanned Systems Industry Members Receive Prestigious Awards|url=http://www.hydro-international.com/news/id1388-Unmanned_Systems_Industry_Members_Receive_Prestigious_Awards.html|publisher=Hydro International|accessdate=27 June 2011|date=13 September 2006}} She received the DEMO God Award at the [[DEMO conference|DEMO Conference]]. In 2005, she was named "Entrepreneur of the Year" by [[Good Housekeeping]]{{cite web|title=Good Housekeeping Announces the Winner of 11th Annual Good Buy Awards|date=Dec 1, 2005 |url=http://abcnews.go.com/GMA/story?id=1352226}} and she was named by the [[John F. Kennedy School of Government|Kennedy School at Harvard]] in conjunction with the [[U.S. News & World Report]] as one of "America's Best Leaders."{{cite web|title=How America's Best Leaders Were Picked|url=https://www.usnews.com/news/best-leaders/articles/2008/11/19/how-americas-best-leaders-were-picked|website=USNews|publisher=US News and World Report|accessdate=1 May 2015}} In 2003, Greiner and iRobot co-founder [[Colin Angle]] were named [[Ernst and Young]] New England Entrepreneurs of the Year. In 2003, Greiner was named one of the “Top Ten Innovators” by [[Fortune Magazine]]. In 2000, Greiner was also listed as one of the Global Leader of Tomorrow by the [[World Economic Forum]].{{cite web|title=GLT Class of 2000|url=http://www3.weforum.org/docs/WEF_GLT_ClassOf2000.pdf|website=Weforum|publisher=World Economic Forum|accessdate=1 May 2015}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Greiner, Helen}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1967 births]] [[Category:American roboticists]] [[Category:Women in technology]] [[Category:American mechanical engineers]] [[Category:20th-century American businesspeople]]

revision.text:
'''ISO 12083''' (informally known as "AAP markup"<ref>{{Cite book| publisher = The Haworth Press| isbn = 978-1-136-58921-8| pages = 5–16| editors = John J. Riemer (ed.)| last = McCallum| first = Sally| title = Cataloging and Classification Standards and Rules| chapter = What Makes a Standard?| location = New York| date = 1996}}</ref>) is an international [[Standard Generalized Markup Language|SGML]] standard for document interchange between authors and publishers, featuring separate [[Document Type Definition|DTDs]] for books, serials, articles, and math.
== History == In 1983, the [[Association of American Publishers]] (AAP), a coalition of book and journal publishers in North America, launched the Electronic Manuscript Project, the first effort ever to develop a commercial SGML application.<ref name="cave" /> The project sought to create a standard for document interchange that would allow the publishing industry to reap the benefits of [[Markup language#Types|descriptive markup]], which was seen as “the most effective means of establishing a consistent method for preparing electronic manuscripts which can feed the publishing process.”<ref>{{cite news |last1=Association of American Publishers| first1=.|title= Electronic Manuscript Project: Task I Report | publisher=Aspen Systems |place=Rockville, MD| date= 1984| page=7}}</ref>. Key participants in the project included organizations such as the [[US Library of Congress]], the American Society of Indexers, the [[IEEE]], the [[American Chemical Society]], the [[American Institute of Physics]], and the [[American Mathematical Society]].<ref name="cave">{{Cite journal| doi = 10.1108/10650750310698766| issn = 1065-075X| volume = 19| issue = 4| pages = 144–148| last = Cave| first = Francis| title = Article Metadata Standards: An Historical Review| journal = OCLC Systems & Services: International Digital Library Perspectives| date = 2003-12-01}}</ref>
In 1983, Aspen Systems Corporation was hired to conduct the work over a two-year period. Two preliminary works with restricted distribution were produced in 1985, the draft AAP DTD<ref>{{Cite book| publisher = AAP| title = Association of American Publishers' Standard for Electronic Manuscript Preparation and Exchange.| location = Washington| date = 1985}}</ref> and author guidelines.<ref>{{Cite book| publisher = AAP| title = Author Guidelines for the Preparation, Creation and Exchange of Electronic Manuscripts| location = Washington| date = 1985}}</ref><ref name=Smith>{{Cite journal| doi = 10.1093/comjnl/29.3.193| volume = 29| issue = 3| pages = 193–200| last = Smith| first = Joan M.| title = The Implications of SGML for the Preparation of Scientific Publications| journal = The Computer Journal| date = 1986-03-01}}</ref>
In 1986, the Electronic Publishing Special Interest Group (EPSIG), a consortium sponsored by the [[OCLC|Online Computer Library Center]] (OCLC), recommended the DTDs developed by the Electronic Manuscript Project be used as an American Standard.<ref name="cave" /> With the support of the AAP and the Graphic Communications Association (GCA), the recommendations were accepted and, in 1988, the AAP DTD became the [[American National Standards Institute]]'s ''Electronic Manuscript Preparation and Markup'' (ANSI/NISO Z39.59) standard. Being based on the [[ASCII]] [[character encoding]] standard, it includes a large set of entity definitions for special characters.<ref name="Herwijnen-1994-111" />
The AAP and EPSIG continued their collaboration and published a revised version of the specification in 1989,<ref>{{Cite book| publisher = Association of American Publishers, EPSIG| title = Reference Manual on Electronic Manuscript Preparation and Markup (Version 2| location = Dublin, OH, USA| date = 1989}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book| publisher = Association of American Publishers, EPSIG| title = Author’s Guide to Electronic Manuscript Preparation and Markup (Version 2)| location = Dublin, OH, USA| date = 1989}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book| publisher = Association of American Publishers, EPSIG| title = Markup of tabular material (Version 2)| location = Dublin, OH, USA| date = 1989}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book| publisher = Association of American Publishers, EPSIG| title = Markup of mathematical formulas (Version 2)| location = Dublin, OH, USA| date = 1989}}</ref> identifying three document types in the field of publishing: Book, Serial Publication, and Article, for each of which the revised specification offers a DTD.<ref name="auto">{{Cite journal| volume = 16| issue = 2| pages = 103–145| last1 = Goossens| first1 = Michel| last2 = Saarela| first2 = Janne| title = A practical introduction to SGML| journal = TUGboat| date = November 1995}}</ref>
The AAP and the [[European Physical Society]] (EPS) further collaborated on a standard method for marking up tables and mathematical notation in scientific documents.<ref name="auto" /> Building on this work, Eric van Herwijnen, then head of the text processing section at [[CERN]],<ref>{{Cite journal| issn = 0891-2017| volume = 17| issue = 1| pages = 110–116| last = van Ess-Dkema| first = Carol| title = Review of "Practical SGML" by Eric Van Herwijnen. Kluwer Academic Publishers 1990.| journal = Computational Linguistics| date = March 1991}}</ref> edited the specification for adoption by the [[International Organization for Standardization]] as ISO 12083, first published in 1993,<ref name="Herwijnen-1994-111">{{cite book|last=Van Herwijnen|first=Eric|title=Practical SGML|year=1994|publisher=Springer|isbn=978-0-7923-9434-1|page=111}}</ref> revised in 1994<ref>{{Cite web| title = ISO 12083:1994 – Information and documentation -- Electronic manuscript preparation and markup| work = International Organization for Standardization| accessdate = 2017-08-27| date = October 1994| url = https://www.iso.org/standard/20866.html}}</ref> and last reconfirmed in 2016.<ref>{{Cite| publisher = International Organization for Standardization| title = ISO Update, Supplement to ISO Focus| date = February 2016| url=https://www.iso.org/files/live/sites/isoorg/files/news/magazine/ISOupdate/EN/2016/ISOupdate_February_2016.pdf}}</ref> ISO 12083 features four DTDs: Article, Book, Serial, and Math.
== Usage == In practice, ISO 12083 is seldom used in its pure form, yet it is the basis of many DTDs in common use.<ref>{{Cite book| publisher = Columbia University Press| isbn = 978-0-231-12499-7| pages = 65–154| editors = William E. Kasdorf (ed.)| last = Kasdorf| first = William E.| title = The Columbia Guide to Digital Publishing| chapter = Markup: XML & Related Technologies| location = New York| date = 2003}}</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120624040507/http://www.niso.org/apps/group_public/project/details.php?project_id=43 ANSI/NISO Z39.59] * [https://www.iso.org/standard/20866.html ISO 12083:1994] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20000530040619/http://www.xmlxperts.com:80/articledtd.htm ISO 12083 Article DTD] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20000815212917/http://www.xmlxperts.com/xmlbookdtd.htm ISO 12083 Book DTD] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20000613115152/http://www.xmlxperts.com/serialdtd.htm ISO 12083 Serial DTD] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20000312064654/http://www.xmlxperts.com/mathdtd.htm ISO 12083 Math DTD]
[[Category:ISO standards|#12083]] [[Category:Markup languages]] [[Category:Technical communication]]
{{markup-languages-stub}}

revision.comment: consistency of space after comma amended. ~~~~
revision.text:
The International Coalition for Geoinformatics (iGeoInfo) was founded after an inaugural meeting, organized by H. Richard Lane of the [[U.S. National Science Foundation]] (NSF) and Cinzia Cervato (CHRONOS) on Friday 20 August 2004, which took place during the 32nd International Geological Congress in [[Florence]], [[Italy]].<ref>Klump, Jens, Robert Huber, u. a. (2005), Workshop Launches International Coalition for GeoInformatics, EOS, Transactions, American Geophysical Union, 86(3), 27-28.</ref>
The purpose of iGeoInfo was to build a community to promote [[data sharing]] concepts, and [[geoinformatics]] in general, at an international level. Initially, the main focus of iGeoInfo was to foster the collaboration between geoinformatics initiatives in the [[United States]] and [[Europe]] rooted in the fields of [[stratigraphy]], [[sedimentary geology]] and [[paleobiology]].
The founding members of iGeoinfo were scientists from [https://web.archive.org/web/19981205122129/http://www.chronos.org/ Chronos], [http://www.earthchem.org/ EarthChem], [http://www.paleostrat.org PaleoStrat], [http://www.pangaea.de PANGAEA], [http://www.geosamples.org SESAR] and [http://www.stratigraphy.net Stratigraphy.net]. Several other initiatives and programs joined later such as [http://www.geon.org GEON] and [http://www.paleodb.org PaleoDB].
== References ==
{{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.igeoinfo.org International Coalition for Geosciences]
{{DEFAULTSORT:International Coalition For Geoinformatics}} [[Category:Earth sciences organizations]] [[Category:Earth sciences software infrastructure organizations]] [[Category:Geology organizations]] [[Category:Paleontological institutions and organizations]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.6.1)
revision.text:
{{Redirect|Kiviter|the former oil shale company|Viru Keemia Grupp}} {{Infobox industrial process | name = Kiviter process | image = | caption = | type = Chemical | sector = [[Chemical industry]]
[[oil industry]] | technologies = | feedstock = [[oil shale]] | product = [[shale oil]] | companies = [[Viru Keemia Grupp|VKG Oil]]
Kiviõli Keemiatööstus | facility = | inventor = | year = | developer = [[Viru Keemia Grupp|VKG Oil]] }} The '''Kiviter process''' is an above ground retorting technology for [[shale oil extraction]]. ==History== The Kiviter process is based on the earlier vertical retort technology (Pintsch's generator). This technology underwent a long process of development. The early concept of central inlet of the heat carrier was later replaced by a concept of heat carrier gas cross flow in the retort. The Kiviter technology has been used in Estonia since 1921, when first experimental Kiviter retorts were built. {{Cite journal | last1 =Väli | first1 = E. | last2 =Valgma | first2 = I. | last3 =Reinsalu | first3 = E. | title = Usage of Estonian oil shale | journal =Oil Shale. A Scientific-Technical Journal | publisher = Estonian Academy Publishers | volume = 25 | issue = 2 | pages =101–114 | year =2008 | url= http://www.kirj.ee/public/oilshale_pdf/2008/issue_2S/oil-2008-2S-2.pdf | format = PDF | issn = 0208-189X | accessdate =2008-11-23 | doi =10.3176/oil.2008.2S.02}} The first commercial scale oil plant based on the Kiviter technology was built in 1924. {{Cite paper | last = Kattai | first = V. |author2=Lokk, U. | title = Historical review of the kukersite | publisher = Geological Survey of Estonia | date = 1998-02-17 | url= http://deepthought.ttu.ee/maeinst/os/2_katlok.html | accessdate =2008-11-23}} From 1955 to 2003, Kiviter technology was used for oil shale processing also in [[Slantsy, Leningrad Oblast|Slantsy]], Russia. {{Cite book | last = Uustalu | first = Jaan | editor1-last=Rofer | editor1-first= Cheryl K. | editor2-last=Kaasik | editor2-first= Tõnis | title = Turning a Problem Into a Resource: Remediation and Waste Management at the Sillamae Site, Estonia | chapter = Utilization of semi-coke for energy production | publisher = [[Axel Springer AG]] | page = 223 | year =2000 | url= https://books.google.com/books?id=hkTGV56jbI0C&pg=PA223 | isbn = 978-0-7923-6186-2 | accessdate =2008-11-23}} {{cite book |title = Survey of energy resources |publisher = World Energy Council (WEC) |year = 2007 |edition = edition 21 |pages = 93–115 |url = http://www.worldenergy.org/documents/ser2007_final_online_version_1.pdf |format = PDF |isbn = 0-946121-26-5 |accessdate = 2008-11-23 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110409010229/http://www.worldenergy.org/documents/ser2007_final_online_version_1.pdf |archivedate = 2011-04-09 |df = }} {{Cite conference |last1=Leveinen |first1=Jussi |last2=Aneshkin |first2=Boris |last3=Blanchard |first3=Francois |last4=Staudt |first4=Michael |last5=Van den Dool |first5=Gijs |last6=Sapon |first6=Svetlana |last7=Kruglova |first7=Olga |title=Modelling impacts of oil-shale mining on groundwater resources in the Slantsy region, Russia |conference=15th Meeting of the Association of European Geological Societies |date=16–20 September 2007 |location=[[Tallinn]], [[Estonia]] |url= http://www.gi.ee/maegs15/presentations/3_3_Leveinen.ppt |format=PPT |accessdate=2017-05-07 |df= }} ==Technology== The Kiviter process is classified as an internal combustion technology. {{Cite paper | last = Burnham | first = Alan K. | last2 = McConaghy | first2 = James R. | title = Comparison of the acceptability of various oil shale processes | date = 2006-10-16 | place =Golden | publisher = 26th Oil shale symposium | url =https://e-reports-ext.llnl.gov/pdf/341283.pdf | format = PDF | id =UCRL-CONF-226717 | accessdate =2008-11-23 }} The Kiviter retort is a vertical cylindrical vessel that heats coarse oil shale with recycled gases, steam, and air. {{Cite journal | last1 = Jaber | first1 = Jamel O. | last2 = Sladek | first2 = Thomas A. | last3 = Mernitz | first3 = Scott | last4 = Tarawneh | first4 = T. M. | title = Future Policies and Strategies for Oil Shale Development in Jordan | year = 2008 | volume = 2 | issue = 1 | pages = 31–44 | journal = Jordan Journal of Mechanical and Industrial Engineering | url = http://jjmie.hu.edu.jo/files/V2/004-v2-1.pdf | format = PDF | issn = 1995-6665 | accessdate = 2008-11-22}} To supply heat, gases (including produced [[oil shale gas]]) and [[carbonaceous]] [[Spent shale|spent residue]] are burnt within the retort. Raw oil shale is fed into the top of the retort, and is heated by the rising gases, which pass laterally through the descending oil shale causing decomposition of the rock. Pyrolysis is completed in the lower section of the retort, where the spent shale contacted with more hot gas, steam and air is heated to about {{convert|900|°C|°F}} to gasify and burn the residual carbon ([[char]]). [[Shale oil]] vapors and evolving gases are delivered to a condensing system, where condensed shale oil is collected, while non-condensable gases are fed back to the retort. Recycled gas enters the bottom of the retort and cools the spent shale, which then leaves the retort through a water-sealed discharge system. {{Cite journal |last=Koel|first=Mihkel | title=Estonian oil shale | journal=Oil Shale. A Scientific-Technical Journal | publisher=Estonian Academy Publishers | issue=Extra | year=1999 | url=http://www.kirj.ee/public/oilshale/Est-OS.htm | issn=0208-189X | accessdate=2008-11-23}} The Kiviter process uses large amounts of water, which is polluted during processing, and the solid waste residue contains water-soluble toxic substances that leach into the surrounding area. {{Cite journal |last=Mölder |first=Leevi |title=Estonian Oil Shale Retorting Industry at a Crossroads |journal= Oil Shale. A Scientific-Technical Journal |publisher=Estonian Academy Publishers |volume=21 |issue=2 |pages =97–98 |year=2004 |url=http://www.kirj.ee/public/oilshale/1_ed_page_2004_2.pdf |format=PDF |issn=0208-189X | accessdate =2008-11-23}} {{Cite conference | last1= Soone|first1= Jüri | last2=Riisalu | first2= Hella | last3=Kekisheva | first3=Ljudmilla | last4=Doilov | first4=Svjatoslav | title = Environmentally sustainable use of energy and chemical potential of oil shale | pages = 2–3 | publisher = Jordanian Natural Resources Authority | conference = International Oil Shale Conference | date = 2006-11-07 | location = [[Amman]], [[Jordan]] | url=http://www.sdnp.jo/International_Oil_Conference/rtos-A104.pdf | format=PDF | accessdate = 2007-06-29}} ==Commercial use== The Kiviter process is used by the Estonian [[Viru Keemia Grupp]]'s subsidiary VKG Oil. {{Cite paper | title =Strategic significance of America’s oil shale resource. Volume II: Oil shale resources, technology and economics | publisher= Office of Deputy Assistant Secretary for Petroleum Reserves; Office of Naval Petroleum and Oil Shale Reserves; [[United States Department of Energy]] | year=2004 | url=http://www.fossil.energy.gov/programs/reserves/npr/publications/npr_strategic_significancev2.pdf | format=PDF | accessdate =2008-11-23 }} The company operates several Kiviter retorts, the largest of them having a processing capacity of 40 tonnes per hour of oil shale feedstock. {{Cite paper |title=An Assessment of Oil Shale Technologies |date=June 1980 |url=http://www.princeton.edu/~ota/disk3/1980/8004/8004.PDF |format=PDF |id=NTIS order #PB80-210115 |accessdate=2008-11-23}} ==See also== * [[Oil shale in Estonia]] * [[Alberta Taciuk Process]] * [[Petrosix]] * [[Galoter process]] * [[TOSCO II process]] * [[Fushun process]] * [[Paraho process]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} [[Category:Oil shale technology]] [[Category:Oil shale in Estonia]]

revision.comment: Fixed opinionated material to be more objective.
revision.text:
{{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}} '''Knockdown Texture''' is a [[drywall]] finishing style. It is a mottled texture, more intense than a simple flat finish, but less intense than [[Orange peel (effect)|orange peel]], or [[Popcorn ceiling|popcorn]], texture. [[Image:Knockdown texture.jpg|right|thumb|Heavy knockdown applied with a spray hopper.]] Knockdown texture is created by watering down [[joint compound]] to a soupy consistency. A [[trowel]] is then used to apply the joint compound. The joint compound will begin to form [[stalactite]]s as it dries. The trowel is then run over the surface of the drywall, knocking off the stalactites and leaving the mottled finish.
A much more common, and faster technique is to apply the texture mud (which is slightly different from joint compound, in that it has less shrinkage upon drying) with a texture machine – a compressor which sprays mud instead of paint. This applies what is referred to as a splatter coat. The use of a compressor allows this to be applied to walls as well as ceilings. When knocking this down, the mud is allowed to dry for a short period, then skimmed with a knockdown knife – a large, usually plastic (to reduce noticeable edges) knife.
Knockdown texture reduces construction costs because it conceals imperfections in the drywall that normally require higher more expensive stages of sand and prime for drywall installers.
{{DEFAULTSORT:Knockdown Texture}} [[Category:Construction]]

revision.comment: /* Reception */ link Sharpie
revision.text:
[[File:Labelflash-Logo.svg|right|200px]] [[File:LabelFlash.jpg|thumb|A Labelflash disc engraved with an image of the planet [[Jupiter]].]] '''Labelflash''' (sometimes written '''LabelFlash''') is a technology which allows users to burn custom designs or images onto proprietary [[DVD]] media first announced in October 2005 as a collaboration between [[Yamaha]] and [[Fujifilm]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com.ph/books?id=gXaRdKyD4PsC&pg=PA602&lpg=PA602&dq=LabelFlash+announcement&source=bl&ots=fMnZ1ERv_3&sig=ssb8n519CCPiZGvm3waLIcb5T4I&hl=en&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwjR8YT-w8zeAhUJe7wKHZxTAyoQ6AEwDnoECAgQAQ#v=onepage&q=LabelFlash%20announcement&f=false|title=Upgrading and Repairing PCs: Upgrading and Repairing_c21|last=Mueller|first=Scott|date=2013-03-07|publisher=Que Publishing|isbn=9780133105360|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.letsgodigital.org/en/news/articles/story_4912.html|title=FujiFilm and Yamaha LabelFlash Technology|last=Peters|first=Mark|date=2005-10-24|website=LetsGoDigital|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-11}}</ref> While Yamaha developed the optical drives, Fujifilm manufactured the proprietary Labelflash optical discs.<ref>"[http://link.galegroup.com/apps/doc/A137729661/GPS?sid=wikipedia YAMAHA, FUJIFILM DEVELOP LASER TECHNOLOGY TO ILLUSTRATE DVD]." ''AsiaPulse News'', 20 Oct. 2005. ''General OneFile''. Accessed 12 Nov. 2018.</ref> [[NEC]] manufactured the first Labelflash compatible drive, the ND4551,<ref name=":0" /> which was released in December 2005.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.myce.com/article/First-Look-Labelflashtrade-235/|title=First Look: Labelflash™ - Myce.com|work=Myce.com|access-date=2018-11-12|language=en-US}}</ref>
Burning Labelflash media is supported by [[Nero Burning ROM]] version 7 and newer.<ref>[http://www.nero.com/nero7/eng/Nero_Burning_ROM_Release_Notes.php 7.0.2.8] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927220724/http://www.nero.com/nero7/eng/Nero_Burning_ROM_Release_Notes.php |date=2007-09-27 }}</ref> Yamaha partnered with [[Toshiba]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://books.google.com.ph/books?id=vLk-j6jSsWkC&pg=PA30|title=First Looks: Bargain Laptop Colossus|last=|first=|date=2007-10-02|work=PC Magazine|access-date=|page=30}}</ref> and [[Gateway, Inc.|Gateway]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://books.google.com.ph/books?id=s9Dc1sn8wpwC&pg=PA36|title=First Looks Hardware: Junior 3D Gaming Rig|last=|first=|date=2008-05-01|work=PC Magazine|access-date=|page=36}}</ref> to provide Labelflash as a feature in computers made by those companies.
Production of Labelflash media was halted on December 22, 2016.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://labelflash.jp/jp/news.html|title=News|last=|first=|date=2016-12-22|website=The Official Website of Labelflash™|publisher=Yamaha, Inc|archive-url=http://web.archive.org/web/20170224152915/http://labelflash.jp/jp/news.html|archive-date=2017-02-24|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-13}}</ref> Labelflash was officially discontinued in 2017.<ref name=":1" />
== Technical details == In Labelflash, the standard recording head of an optical drive is repurposed to burn images onto a layer of dye made for this purpose on the top of proprietary Labelflash optical media.<ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|last=Kubo|first=Hiroshi|last2=Shibata|first2=Michihiro|last3=et|first3=al|displayauthors=2|date=June 2007|title=New Laser Labeling Technology for Recordable Digital Versatile Disc|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/239054916_New_Laser_Labeling_Technology_for_Recordable_Digital_Versatile_Disc|journal=Japanese Journal of Applied Physics|volume=46|pages=3926-3927|doi=10.1143/JJAP.46.3926|via=ResearchGate}}</ref> The dye is 0.6mm below the surface so as to protect it from the elements.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://www.belightsoft.com/products/resources/lightscribe-vs-labelflash|title=LightScribe VS. Labelflash: A Disc Labeling Cold War|last=East III|first=Raymond|date=2009-07-01|website=Belight|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-12}}</ref><ref name=":2" />
The [[Display resolution|resolution]] is adjustable between 300 and 1800 dpi (dots per inch). Up to 256 monochromatic shades can be used in the image.<ref name=":0">"[http://link.galegroup.com/apps/doc/A141256966/GPS?sid=wikipedia Integrator Trade Only - Hardware - DVD rewriter - NEC ND4551. Fast DVD rewriter with built-in label writer. Rating: 5 out of 5]." ''Computer Reseller News'' [UK], 23 Jan. 2006, p. 38. ''General OneFile''. Accessed 12 Nov. 2018.</ref> The labeling process takes 7 minutes at the lowest resolution and a half hour at the highest.<ref name=":0" /> Labelflash is [[backwards compatible]] with Yamaha's earlier [[DiscT@2]] technology—this allows Labelflash-compatible optical drives to engrave onto the data side of discs as well.
According to Yamaha, a new iteration of Labelflash which supported four color printing was in the works<ref name=":4" />—however, as Labelflash support was discontinued in 2017,<ref name=":1" /> this never came to fruition.
== Reception == The technology is often compared with [[Hewlett-Packard]]'s [[LightScribe]], released one year earlier. After its release, Labelflash was not available in the United States until 2007,<ref name=":2">"[http://link.galegroup.com/apps/doc/A164944722/GPS?sid=wikipedia Fujifilm Rolls Out Labelflash DVD Media to U.S. Market]" ''Wireless News'', 13 June 2007. ''General OneFile''. Accessed 12 Nov. 2018.</ref> giving HP a three year head start in the US market. Furthermore, worldwide, proprietary Labelflash optical media costed double that of comparable LightScribe media,<ref name=":1" /> at US$2.40 per disc,<ref name=":3">{{Cite news|url=https://www.tomshardware.com/reviews/labelflash-lightscribe-dvd,1219.html|title=Labelflash vs LightScribe DVD/CD Labeling|last=Moersch|first=Siggy|date=2006-02-14|work=Tom's Hardware|access-date=2018-11-12|language=en}}</ref><ref name=":5" /> which ''[[Tom's Hardware]]'' called an "exorbitant" price that made printing "painful" as test prints were not worth doing.<ref name=":3" /> Commenting on the price, ''[[Engadget]]''<nowiki/>'s Marc Perton said he'd "stick with [his] [[Sharpie (marker)|Sharpie]] for now."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.engadget.com/2006/02/14/labelflash-vs-lightscribe-toms-goes-for-the-burn/|title=LabelFlash vs. LightScribe: Tom's goes for the burn|last=Perton|first=Marc|date=2006-02-14|work=Engadget|access-date=2018-11-12|language=en-US}}</ref>
Reviewers, such as Gordon Laing for [[Personal Computer World|''Personal Computer World'']], also noted that when compared to LightScribe, Labelflash images looked more "unnatural" and less "vibrant".<ref name=":5">{{Cite news|url=https://archive.org/details/Personal_Computer_World_2006-05_VNU_Business_Publications_GB/page/n117?q=labelflash|title=Add style with flash labels|last=Laing|first=Gordon|date=2006-05-01|work=Personal Computer World|access-date=2018-11-12|pages=51, 124}}</ref>
==See also== *[[DiscT@2]] *[[LabelTag]] *[[LightScribe]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links==
* [https://web.archive.org/web/20090716211258/http://labelflash.jp/ Official Labelflash site]
[[Category:Computer storage media]] [[Category:Consumer electronics]]

revision.text:
[[File:Vickers machine gun in the Battle of Passchendaele - September 1917.jpg|thumb|right|300px|A [[Vickers machine gun]] in the [[battle of the Menin Road Ridge]]]] This is a list of infantry weapons of [[World War I]] (1914–1918).
=={{Flagicon|Democratic Republic of Armenia}} [[First Republic of Armenia|Republic of Armenia]]==
'''Sidearms'''
*[[Mauser C96]] *[[Mauser Zig-Zag|Mauser M1878]] *[[Nagant M1895]]
'''Rifles'''
*[[Berdan rifle|Berdan M1870]] *[[Fusil Gras mle 1874|Gras M1874]] *[[Mauser Model 1871|Mauser M1887]] *[[Mosin–Nagant|Mosin–Nagant M1891]] *[[Martini–Henry#Turkish, Romanian, and Boer Republics Peabody–Martini–Henry rifles|Peabody–Martini–Henry M1874]]
'''Machine guns'''
*[[PM M1910|Maxim M1910]]
=={{flag|Australia|1940|name=Commonwealth of Australia}}==
'''Sidearms'''
*[[Enfield revolver|Enfield Mark II]] *[[Webley Revolver|Webley Mark VI]]
'''Rifles'''
*[[Lee–Metford|Lee–Metford Mk I and Mk II]] *[[Lee–Enfield#Magazine Lee–Enfield|Magazine Lee–Enfield Mk I]] *[[Lee–Enfield#Short Magazine Lee–Enfield Mk I|Short Magazine Lee–Enfield Mk III]]
'''Machine guns'''

revision.comment: Added "NCsim"
revision.text:
'''ModelSim''' is a multi-language HDL simulation environment by [[Mentor Graphics]],<ref name="b1"/> for simulation of [[hardware description language]]s such as [[VHDL]], [[Verilog]] and [[SystemC]], and includes a built-in C debugger.<ref name="b2">[https://books.google.com/books?id=F-mTrH1NB4UC&pg=PA97&dq=ModelSim&hl=en&sa=X#v=onepage&q=ModelSim&f=false Reconfigurable Embedded Control Systems], Idea Group Inc (IGI), 30-Nov-2010</ref><ref name="b1"/> ModelSim can be used independently, or in conjunction with [[Altera Quartus|Intel Quartus Prime]], [[Xilinx ISE]] or [[Xilinx Vivado]].<ref name="b5">[https://books.google.com/books?id=wUALmyy9YUcC&pg=PA41&dq=ModelSim&hl=en&sa=X#v=onepage&q=ModelSim&f=false Digital Hardware Design], Laxmi Publications, Ltd., 01-Sep-2008</ref> Simulation is performed using the [[graphical user interface]] (GUI), or automatically using scripts. <ref name="b7">[https://books.google.com/books?id=ljLBBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA17&dq=ModelSim&hl=en&sa=X#v=onepage&q=ModelSim&f=false Synthesizable VHDL Design for FPGAs], Springer Science & Business Media, 21-Oct-2013</ref>
==Editions== Mentor HDL simulation products are offered in multiple editions, such as ModelSim PE and Questa Sim.
Questa Sim offers high-performance and advanced debugging capabilities, while ModelSim PE is the entry-level simulator for hobbyists and students.<ref name="b1">[https://books.google.com/books?id=Eqgrqktkk1YC&pg=PA606&dq=ModelSim&hl=en&sa=X#v=onepage&q=ModelSim&f=false Handbook of Digital Techniques for High-Speed Design], Pearson Education India, 01-Sep-2007</ref> Questa Sim is used in large multi-million gate designs, and is supported on [[Microsoft Windows]] and Linux, in 32-bit and 64-bit architectures.<ref name="b1"/>
ModelSim can also be used with [[MATLAB]]/[[Simulink]], using ''Link for ModelSim''.<ref name="b6">[https://books.google.com/books?id=cnkYRKhUwyEC&pg=PA849&dq=ModelSim&hl=en&sa=X#v=onepage&q=ModelSim&f=false Industrial Control Technology], William Andrew, 12-Aug-2008</ref><ref name="b4">[https://books.google.com/books?id=pJSqZZmc9_oC&pg=PA168&dq=ModelSim&hl=en&sa=X#v=onepage&q=ModelSim&f=false Recent Advances in Modeling and Simulation Tools for Communication Networks and Services], Springer Science & Business Media, 20-Sep-2007</ref> ''Link for ModelSim'' is a fast bidirectional co-simulation interface between Simulink and ModelSim.<ref name="b4"/><ref name="b6"/> For such designs, MATLAB provides a numerical simulation toolset, while ModelSim provides tools to verify the hardware implementation & timing characteristics of the design.<ref name="b4"/>
==Language support== ModelSim uses a unified kernel for simulation of all supported languages, and the method of debugging embedded C code is the same as VHDL or Verilog.<ref name="b1"/>
ModelSim and Questa Sim products enable simulation, verification and debugging for the following languages:<ref name="b1"/> *[[VHDL]] *[[Verilog]] *[[Verilog]] 2001 *[[SystemVerilog]] *[[Property Specification Language|PSL]] *[[SystemC]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==See also== * [[Altera Quartus]] * [[Icarus Verilog]] * [[List of HDL simulators]] * [[NCSim]] * [[Verilator]] * [[Xilinx ISE]] * [[Xilinx Vivado]]
==External links== * {{Official website|https://www.mentor.com/products/fpga/verification-simulation/modelsim/}}
{{Programmable Logic}}

page.title: Monument to the Conquerors of Space

revision.comment: /* Location and surroundings */ Name was changed back.
revision.text:
[[File:RIAN_archive_557655_Second_Moscow_Watch_Factory_locksmith%27s_family.jpg|right|thumb|Monument to the Conquerors of Space]] {{coord|55|49|22|N|37|38|24|E|type:landmark|display=title}} [[File:MonumentConquerorsSpace00.jpeg|thumb|Monument to the Conquerors of Space]] The '''''Monument to the Conquerors of Space''''' ({{lang-rus|Монуме́нт «Покори́телям ко́смоса»|r=Monumént "Pokorítelyam kósmosa"|p=mənʊˈmʲent pəkɐrʲˈitʲɪlʲɪm ˈkosməsə}}) was erected in [[Moscow]] in 1964 to celebrate achievements of the [[Soviet people]] in space exploration. It depicts a starting rocket that rises on its exhaust plume. The monument is 107 meters (351 feet) tall, has 77° incline, and is made of [[titanium]].{{cite web|url=http://www.museum.ru/M329 |title=Memorial Museum of Cosmonautics website |publisher=Museum.ru |date= |accessdate=2011-10-14}} The [[Memorial Museum of Cosmonautics]] is located inside the base of the monument. ==Location and surroundings== The monument is located outside the main entry to today's [[VDNKh (Russia)|Exhibition of Achievements of the National Economy]] (''VDNKh''), in the northeastern part of Moscow, near Prospekt Mira ("Peace Avenue"). The easiest access is from the [[VDNKh (Metro)|VDNKh subway station]]. Since the 1960s, this part of Moscow in general has had a high concentration of space-themed sights and names: besides the monument and the museum under it, the grand "Cosmos" pavilion in the Exhibition Centre displayed many artifacts of the [[Soviet space program]]. Many streets in the area have been named after the precursors of the space program ([[Nikolai Kibalchich]], [[Friedrich Zander]], [[Yuri Kondratyuk]]) and its participants ([[Sergey Korolyov]]). The [[Cosmonauts Alley]] south of the monument features [[bust (sculpture)|busts]] of Soviet cosmonauts. The choice of this part of Moscow for space-related names and monuments may have been inspired by the fact that Prospekt Mira runs toward the north-eastern suburbs of Moscow, where, in [[Korolyov (city)|Podlipki]] (today's Korolyov City) much of the space program was based. [[Sergey Korolyov|Korolyov]] himself lived in a house within a few blocks from the monument, which is now preserved as Korolyov Memorial Museum ({{lang-ru|Дом-музей академика С. П. Королёва}}). ==History== In March 1958, a few months after the launch of ''[[Sputnik 1]]'', a competition was announced for the best design of an obelisk celebrating the dawn of the [[Space Age]]. Out of some 350 proposals, the design by [[sculptor]] [[A.P. Faidysh-Krandievsky]] and architects [[A.N. Kolchin]] and [[M.O. Barshch]] was chosen. The grand opening of the monument took place on October 4, 1964, on the day of the 7th anniversary of the ''Sputnik 1'' launch. The monument was designed to accommodate a museum in its base. However, it took until April 10, 1981 (two days before the 20th anniversary of [[Yuri Gagarin]]'s flight) to complete the preparatory work and open the [[Memorial Museum of Cosmonautics]]. The museum reopened on April 12, 2009 after three years of renovations. ==Design and sculpture== [[File:Monumentos a los Conquistadores del Espacio 04.JPG|thumbnail|right|Front of the stone base]] The main part of the monument is a giant [[obelisk]] topped by a rocket and resembling in shape the exhaust plume of the rocket. It is 107 meters (350 feet) tall and, on Korolyov's suggestion, covered with [[titanium]] cladding. A statue of [[Konstantin Tsiolkovsky]], the precursor of astronautics, is located in front of the obelisk. A poem in Russian on the front of the stone base of the monument base says: {{quotation|И наши тем награждены усилья,
Что поборов бесправие и тьму,
Мы отковали пламенные крылья
:Своей ::Стране :::И веку своему!}} Approximate translation: {{quotation|And our efforts are rewarded,
we have overcome powerlessness and darkness,
We've forged these flaming wings.
:For our ::Nation :::And this age of ours!}} Below, in smaller letters, is the dedicatory statement: "В ознаменование выдающихся достижений советского народа в освоении космического пространства сооружен этот монумент" ("This monument was constructed to celebrate the outstanding achievements of the Soviet people in space exploration"), and the year, 1964. Both sides of the monument base, in their front parts, are decorated with [[high relief|haut-]] and [[bas-reliefs]] depicting men and women of the [[Soviet space program|space program]]: scientists, engineers, workers, their occupations indicated by appropriate accoutrements of the professions. Notable figures include a [[computer programmer]] (or perhaps some other computing or telecommunications professional) holding a [[punched tape]], a [[cosmonaut]] wearing a space suit, and [[Laika]] the space dog, first animal to orbit Earth. No contemporary Soviet politicians are depicted in the monument either (that would violate the convention existing in the post-[[Joseph Stalin]] [[Soviet Union]] against commemorating living persons in this fashion), but the crowd on the right side of the monument are moving forward under the banner of [[Vladimir Lenin]]. ==The monument reflected in other media== The ''Monument to the Conquerors of Space'' is featured on the 1967 ten-[[Soviet Ruble|kopeck]] piece, one of the series of the [[Commemorative coins of the Soviet Union|commemorative coins]] issued to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the [[October Revolution]]. This coin has the distinction of being the smallest-denomination commemorative coin ever minted in the Soviet Union. (It was the smallest coin in the 1967 series—the only time commemorative fractional currency coins were ever produced in the USSR. All later commemorative coins were either 1 [[ruble]], or a higher denomination). Image:Soviet Union-1967-Coin-0.10. 50 Years of Soviet Power.jpg|10 kopeck anniversary coin celebrating 50 years of the October Revolution. File:Km Grafik2 PC300015.jpg|Posters evocative of the monument's design. The Monument is also featured in the music video "[[Go West (song)|Go West]]" by [[Pet Shop Boys]]. Also monument featured in the music video "[[Sweet Lullaby (song)|Sweet Lullaby]]" by [[Deep Forest]]. The monument is depicted on the home kit for the [[Russia national football team]] for the [[2014 FIFA World Cup]] on the front of the shirts in different shades of maroon. ==Replicas== [[File:Боровск КЭЦ.JPG|thumb|right|Tsiolkovsky monument in Borovsk]] The monument to [[Konstantin Tsiolkovsky]] in downtown [[Borovsk]], designed by Sergey Bychkov, contains a nearly exact scale replica of the ''Conquerors of Space'' "rocket needle" and a whimsical statue of Tsiolkovsky gazing into the skies (and wearing [[valenki]] boots). It was unveiled in 2007. A copy of this statue (but not the "rocket needle") is installed at the [[Sir Thomas Brisbane Planetarium]]. A copy is also exhibited in the park of the United Nations Office in Geneva, a gift donated by the USSR and designed by the architect Alexander Koltchin and sculptor Yuri Neroda.http://www.unog.ch/80256EE600581D0E/(httpPages)/1CF0E20D6BC97A1680256EF700594A1C?OpenDocument ==See also== * [[Memorial Museum of Astronautics]] * [[Cosmonauts Alley]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Monument to the Conquerors of Space}} *[http://www.cosmomuseum.ru/ Official Site of the Memorial Museum of Cosmonautics] {{Ru icon}} *[http://www.museum.ru/M329 Memorial Museum of Cosmonautics] {{Ru icon}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070122173115/http://svao.mos.ru/about/places/cosmos/ Monuments to the Conquerors of Space] (Official site of Moscow's [[North-Eastern Administrative Okrug]]) {{Ru icon}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070929091323/http://www.kultura-portal.ru/tree_new/cultpaper/article.jsp?number=635&rubric_id=218 Anna Martovitskaya, "The Launch Vehicle: Cosmonautics Museum is preparing for a renovation"] (''Kultura'', No.14 (7524) 13–16 April 2006) {{Ru icon}} *[http://www.rg.ru/2006/08/02/museo-kosm.html Kristina Polishchuk, "Cosmonautics Museum will soon surprise its visitors with new exhibits"] (''Rossiyskaya Gazeta'', 2 August 2006) {{Ru icon}} *[http://russianuniverse.org/2013/04/03/monument-to-the-conquerors-of-space/ The Monument to the Conquerors of Space] {{DEFAULTSORT:Monument To The Conquerors Of Space}} [[Category:Buildings and structures completed in 1964]] [[Category:Soviet and Russian space program locations]] [[Category:History of spaceflight]] [[Category:Outdoor sculptures in Russia]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Moscow]] [[Category:Monuments and memorials built in the Soviet Union]] [[Category:Monuments and memorials in Moscow]] [[Category:Animal monuments]] [[Category:VDNKh (Russia)]]

revision.text:
{{multiple issues| {{more footnotes|date=January 2014}} {{notability|Biographies|date=February 2014}} }}
{{Infobox artist | name = Myriam Thyes | native_name = | native_name_lang = de | image = Myriam-thyes-2007-portrait.jpg | alt = | caption = portrait of Myriam Thyes, 2007 | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth year and age|1963}} <!-- {{Birth date and age|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | birth_place = [[Luxembourg]] | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | death_place = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{Coord|LAT|LON|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} --> | nationality = Swiss | spouse = | field = [[new media]] | training = Nan Hoover | alma_mater = [[Zurich University of the Arts]], [[Kunstakademie Düsseldorf]] | movement = | works = 'Flag Metamorphoses' | patrons = | awards = | memorials = | elected = | website = {{URL|http://www.thyes.com/}} | bgcolour = | module = }}
'''Myriam Thyes''' (born 1963 in [[Luxembourg]]) is a [[new media artist]] from Switzerland. She lives and works in [[Düsseldorf]].
[[File:Museum-Baerengasse-Zurich-Thyes-2013.jpg|thumb|RaumWelten, Museum Baerengasse, Zürich, 2013]] [[File:Thyes-maltaasmetaphor-shedhalle-zurich.jpg|thumb|Malta As Metaphor, Shedhalle Zürich, 2011]] [[File:Flagmetamorphoses-hallezehn-cologne-2010.jpg|thumb|Flag Metamorphoses, Halle Zehn, CAP Cologne, Cologne, 2010]] [[File:Triennale-germanflaghistory.jpg|thumb|Flag Metamorphoses, Zeppelin Museum Friedrichshafen, 2008]] [[File:Urbanscreens-manchester-flagmetamorphoses.jpg|thumb|Flag Metamorphoses, Urban Screens Manchester, 2007]]
== Biography == Myriam Thyes was born in Luxembourg and grew up in [[Zürich]]. After getting certificate of higher education entrance, she studied at Hoehere Schule für Gestaltung Zurich, now ZHdK [[Zurich University of the Arts]], Switzerland. 1986 to 1992, the artist studied at the Academy of Fine Arts Düsseldorf, [[Kunstakademie Düsseldorf]], painting with Professor Rissa, and video art with Professor [[Nan Hoover]]. She received a degree 'Meisterschueler' from [[Kunstakademie Düsseldorf]]. Since 1994, Thyes participates in exhibitions and festivals internationally.<ref>http://www.duesseldorf.de/kuenstlerleben/index.php?p=suche/kuenstlerleben/bildende_kuenstler/detail&id=454&ref=liste&page=1&Name=T duesseldorf.de Retrieved 21 February 2014.</ref><ref name=videokunst.ch>http://www.videokunst.ch/index.asp?Inhalt=kuenstler.asp&Id=713&Md=1&Stufe=0 videokunst.ch Retrieved 21 February 2014.</ref>
Since 1999, main artistic media of Myriam Thyes are video art, 2D computer animation, photography, and digital imagery. From beginning of 2000 she initiates and realizes as well participatory projects and media art projects in public space. She co-founded artist group '''Strictly Public''' <ref>{{cite book|title=Pixels and Places – Video Art in Public Space|year=2010|publisher=NAi Publishers|location=Rotterdam|pages=5, 27, 56, 61, 134, 147, 148|isbn=978-90-5662-738-6|author=Catrien Schreuder}}</ref> who were invited to participate at Berlin media art festival transmediale.04. Already in 2000 and 2001, Strictly Public showed video art at 9 metro stations in North Rhine-Westphalia (Germany), and 2002 in 26 main stations of the federal railroad all over Germany. Among Thyes's video art works in these programs was 'A little Meditation', the animation of the yin yang symbol, shown for example on the big screen at Frankfurt/Main central station.<ref>{{cite book|title=Pixels and Places – Video Art in Public Space|year=2010|publisher=NAi Publishers|location=Rotterdam|pages=55, 56, 61, 121, 122, 147|isbn=978-90-5662-738-6|author=Catrien Schreuder}}</ref><ref>[http://www.strictlypublic.org/projekte/bahn-db-2002/index.html] artworks! - video art at the Deutsche Bahn in 26 central stations in Germany, Sep. - Nov. 2002</ref>
[[LA Freewaves]]: Video art could be seen on monitors in stores and on billboards on Sunset Boulevard at the then new media festival 2004 in Los Angeles under artistic director Anne Bray. Cathrien Schreuder: "Myriam Thyes's work '''A Little Meditation''' on Sunset Boulevard in Hollywood is a good example. In order to maintain its own form, her animated yin-yang symbol 'fights against the influences of commerce, and in doing so wrests a place for itself in the streetscape. Employing a universal idiom, Thyes visualizes the imbalance within the force field of oublic space. (...) The fact that the work is a good supplement to the streetscape on which it has been shown, including the screens in the train stations of Düsseldorf, the Victory Park Screens in Dallas <ref>[[Victory Park, Dallas]]</ref> and various screens in Bern, Bosnia, Melbourne, Manchester <ref>[[BBC Big Screen]] Manchester</ref> and Dublin." <ref>{{cite book|title=Pixels and Places – Video Art in Public Space|year=2010|publisher=NAi Publishers|location=Rotterdam|page=55,147,121|isbn=978-90-5662-738-6|author=Catrien Schreuder}}</ref>
Thyes' themes deal with symbols, myths and visual signs from architecture, politics, movies, and religions, but as well mythical characters from Hollywood movies, and female characters form different cultures and epochs.<ref name=Wells>{{cite book|title=Re-Imagining Animation: The Changing Face of the Moving Image|year=2008|publisher=AVA Academia|location=Lausanne|pages=63–67|isbn=2940373698|author=Paul Wells, Johnny Hardstaff}}</ref>
Thyes is represented by the media art foundation '[[Imai – inter media art institute]]' (Germany) and videokunst.ch (Switzerland). She is member of [[Deutscher Künstlerbund]] (visual artists association, Germany) and Visarte (visual artists association, Switzerland).
== Works == One of her best known works – frequently shown in exhibitions and festivals internationally – is the participatory animation project '''Flag Metamorphoses'''.<ref name="Catrien Schreuder 2010 56">{{cite book|title=Pixels and Places – Video Art in Public Space|year=2010|publisher=NAi Publishers|location=Rotterdam|page=56|isbn=978-90-5662-738-6|author=Catrien Schreuder}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Mediatektur|year=2010|publisher=Springer-Verlag|location=Wien New York|pages=178–179|isbn=978-3-7091-0302-9|author=Christoph Kronhagel}}</ref> She started in 2005 a continuously growing series of Flash animations concerning flags, other national symbols, and relations between countries. It's a work about relations between nations and identities: each artist who creates a flag animation expresses such a relation in his or her own way. So far, the series contains 40 animations by 30 international artists and teams. All animations together include about 100 different nations. Professor Paul Wells about Flag Metamorphoses in his book ''Re-Imagining Animation'': "Thyes's work is a very particular response to what she describes a very human 'double wish' to have both an individual identity and yet belong to a bigger group, often represented through nations, which are themselves 'imagined communities'. On her choice of flags as iconic Stimuli, Thyes recognises that their symbolism often endures beyond the actual conditions a nation lives through, sometimes remaining largely aspirational (...) Working in such a direct and politicised way, Thyes saw the opportunity to embrace both a democratic approach to the creation of work responsive to a core theme while engaging with other artists, but also in relation to its dissemination to a global audience on the World Wide Web. (...) Inevitably, this level of engagement prompts differing approaches and levels of interrogation. The political level looks at relationships between neighbouring countries, colonial ties and cultural imperialism. On the other hand, the artistic level examines the collapse and revision of largely geometric forms into more amorphous, organic and fluid configurations. (...) Thyes recognised that the key concept of changing cultures was readily revealed through the use of animation's core language of metamorphosis, and in the way animation could reveal and yet challenge the dense meanings embedded in national image systems. (...) Conceptually, Thyes felt that the best results might be achieved if the metamorphoses themselves took place within a single frame: 'What I have in mind is generally one changing image, not a film with scenes and cuts.' (...) This use of the formalist limits of the frame, while addressing the conditions of transition and meaning within it, reflects Thyes's background and identity as a visual artist. The particular influence of Russian Constructivism and the work of the Bauhaus movement are reflected in her collage technique and political satire." <ref name="Wells"/> In the 1990s, she had worked with real flags as installations in public areas: She created and painted new designs and symbols on flags and hung them beside and between official flags in Dusseldorf and Luxembourg.
Thyes participated in the ''Art Colony Galichnik'' in Macedonia in Summer 2010. Artists and curators from various Balkan countries worked together. Thyes asked her subjects to answer in their mother tongues (Serbian/Croatian/Bosnian, Macedonian, Bulgarian and Albanian) and then subtitled their replies into English. She created a collage of images and voices in a two-channel video installation, called '''From Art Colony Galichnik with love (Macedonia 2010)'''. "Thyes documents the thoughts of her subjects and combines their words with shots of the countryside. She creates a sensitive picture of the different personalities and characters, partly by matching the two sets of images. The shots of landscapes and towns depict the origins of the person speaking or emphasise the content of what is being said. Thyes, who has Swiss and Luxembourgian roots, puts the individual at the heart of her work. In doing so, she teils a story of the human needs that exist together at a specific point and place in time - and that, ultimately, reflect the needs that people experience at any time and anywhere in the world." <ref>Katrin Weber, cite catalogue: Ostrale'013 - we cross the Rubicon. 2013. Dresden</ref>
The series of photos and photomontages '''Glasgow Styles'''<ref>http://davis-museum-artblog.blogspot.de/2012/01/myriam-thyes-glasgow-styles-magnify.html</ref> reflect the artist's impressions of the post-industrial city of Glasgow and her inhabitants. Thyes has drawn a social portrait and created a kind of contemporary "Historienbilder" (historical paintings). Michael Staab in ''The Whole Picture. Second Take'' about this work: "... Now, in her series entitled Glasgow Styles, Myriam Thyes takes the consistent next step, and combines the realistic, serial and documentary potential of photography with the formative, allegorising and metaphor-creating traditions of the fine arts. She compiles individual snapshots into sequences that make lapses of time and changes of perspective visible, and also mounts photographs taken at geographically differing locations and at staggered points in time into altogether new pictorial inventions. The citizens of Glasgow, some of them mounted into the original pictures, happened to be at other locations in the same town at the time the pictures were taken. Thus the right people are in the pictures, only, as stated above, at a different place and at another time. The divergence thus highlighted between space, time and individual remains tangible in Thyes’s works, and conveys to the viewer a profound sense of the mood of the people in this city. ..." <ref name=Staab>{{cite book|title=Myriam Thyes – Glasgow Styles / Magnify Malta by Kunstverein Duisburg|year=2012|publisher=Kehrer Artbooks|location=Heidelberg|isbn=978-3-86828-276-4|author=Michael Staab}}</ref>
Malcolm Dickson, director of Street Level Photoworks in Glasgow, in his text ''Glasgow Styles'': "Myriam Thyes's series Glasgow Styles delineates how Glasgow as a contemporary city reflects its past through the present. Initially what seems like a random visual derive is coherently held together through a detailed narrative that the artist has perceptively encountered and which helps to inform Thyes' personal topography of our city. This topography is the city's changing face – a place historically and contemporaneously of contrasts and tensions." <ref name=Dickson>{{cite book|title=Myriam Thyes – Glasgow Styles / Magnify Malta by Kunstverein Duisburg|year=2012|publisher=Kehrer Artbooks|location=Heidelberg|isbn=978-3-86828-276-4|author=Malcolm Dickson}}</ref>
== Major exhibitions and festivals == (C = catalog)
* 1994 Treibhaus 6, [[Museum Kunstpalast]], Düsseldorf. C * 1997 as large as life, <rotor> Kunstverein, steirischer herbst, Graz, Austria. * 2002 International Shortfilm Festival, Hamburg. * 2004 [[Transmediale]], Media Art Festival, Berlin. * 2004 11th Marl Video art Prize, Skulpturenmuseum Glaskasten, Marl. C * 2005 European Media Art Festival EMAF, Osnabrueck. * 2005 KunstFilmBiennale, Koelnischer Kunstverein, Cologne. C * 2005 [[Encounters Short Film and Animation Festival]], Bristol, UK. (Depict!Award for the video ASCENSION) * FILE Festivals, Brazil (São Paulo 2005, Rio de Janeiro 2006, Porto Alegre 2008, São Paulo 2010). C * 2006 Highlights of KunstFilmBiennale, Kunstwerke KW, Berlin. * 2007 Big Screens by Victory Media Network,<ref name="Catrien Schreuder 2010 56"/><ref>{{cite book|title=Mediatektur|year=2010|publisher=Springer-Verlag|location=Wien New York|pages=176–179|isbn=978-3-7091-0302-9|author=Christoph Kronhagel}}</ref> Victory Plaza, Victory Park, Dallas (TX), USA. (Flag Metamorphoses) * 2007 Timeloop – Video art from Germany, Street Level Photoworks, Glasgow, UK. * 2007 WRO 07 International Media Art Biennale, Wroclaw, Poland. * 2007 [[Perpetual Art Machine]] - Video Art in the Age of the Internet. [[Chelsea Art Museum]], New York City. * 2007 Urban Screens, conference ([[Cornerhouse]]) and art events in public space ([[BBC Big Screen]]), Manchester, UK. (Flag Metamorphoses) * 2007 VideoFormes, Clermont-Ferrand, France. * 2008 Politics, Kunstlerhaus Dortmund, Dortmund, Germany.<ref>{{cite web|title=Politics, Kuenstlerhaus Dortmund|url=http://khdortmund.de/Alte_Website/2009/deutsch/aus08/aus08politics.htm}}</ref> * 2008 Nothing to declare. Triennale of Contemporary Art Oberschwaben, [[Zeppelin Museum Friedrichshafen|Zeppelin Museum]], Friedrichshafen, Germany. C * 2009 Speeded Up Flags and Slowed Down Heroes, solo exhibition, Kunstverein Rhein-Sieg, Siegburg, Germany.<ref>{{cite web|title=Myriam Thyes at Kunstverein Rhein-Sieg|url=http://www.kunstverein-rheinsieg.de/ausstellung/archiv/Thyes-Myriam/index.html}}</ref> * 2010 Flag Metamorphoses, Halle Zehn, CAP Cologne, Koeln, Germany. * 2011 Songs of the Swamp, Kunsthalle Exnergasse, Vienna, Austria.<ref>{{cite web|title=Songs of the Swamp, Kunsthalle Exnergasse|url=http://www.wuk.at/event/id/14990}}</ref> * 2011 Connect – Art Between Media and Reality, Shedhalle Zürich, Zurich, Switzerland. C.<ref>{{cite web|title=Connect, Shedhalle Zurich|url=http://archiv2012.shedhalle.ch/en/myriam-thyes-malta-metaphor}}</ref> * 2011 ISEA 2011 Istanbul, Turkey. * 2012 Glasgow Styles / Magnify Malta, solo exhibition, Kunstverein Duisburg, Germany. C.<ref>{{cite web|title=Myriam Thyes at Kunstverein Duisburg|url=http://www.kunstverein-duisburg.de/page1202.html}}</ref> * 2012 Enigma della modernità, Spazio Officina, Chiasso, Switzerland. C * 2012 Images Against Darkness, video art from [[Imai – inter media art institute]]. KIT [[Kunst im Tunnel]], Düsseldorf. C.<ref>{{cite web|title=Images against Darkness|url=http://www.imaionline.de/content/view/204/6/lang,en/|publisher=inter media art institute|accessdate=31 January 2014}}</ref> * 2012 Video Vortex 8, [[Museum of Contemporary Art, Zagreb]], Croatia. * 2012 OSTRALE'012 - Homegrown, Dresden. C * 2013 RaumWelten, Museum Baerengasse, Zurich, Switzerland. * 2013 OSTRALE'013 – we cross the Rubicon, Dresden. C * 2013 SHARE PRIZE – Real Time / Real Space, media art exhibition of Piemonte Share Festival, Accademia di Belle Arti Albertina, Turin, Italy.<ref>{{cite web|title=Share Prize 2013, Turin|url=http://www.toshare.it/toshare09/?page_id=6604}}</ref> * 2014 RAPPORT (with Patricia Lambertus), Kunstverein Schwerin, Germany. * 2015 Dec. - 2016 June: TILL IT'S GONE, [[Istanbul Modern]] / Istanbul Museum of Modern Art, Turkey. Included in '''Art Speaks Out''', video art program by ''ikono TV''.<ref>{{cite web|title=ikono TV, Art Speaks Out|url=http://artspeaksout.ikono.tv|accessdate=10 March 2016}}</ref> * 2016 100 YEARS OF WORLD TRANSITION, Schaumbad - Freies Atelierhaus, Graz, Austria.<ref>{{cite web|title=100 YEARS OF WORLD TRANSITION|url=http://web455.webbox333.server-home.org/index.php?pageid=3&l=2&sid=267|accessdate=9 December 2017}}</ref> * 2017 The Secret Life of Things, Museum Villa Rot, Burgrieden-Rot, Germany.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Secret Life of Things|url=http://www.villa-rot.de/en/info-zur-ausstellung-das-geheime-leben-der-dinge%C2%AC/|accessdate=9 December 2017}}</ref> * 2017 Courant 3D Festival, Angoulême, France.<ref>{{cite web|title=Courant 3D Festival|url=http://www.courant3d-filmfest.com/festival/en/selected-3d-films/|accessdate=9 December 2017}}</ref>

Retrieved 3 February 2014.</ref> * [[Imai – inter media art institute]], Dusseldorf, Germany <ref name="videokunst.ch"/> * Art Collection of the Canton of Zurich, Switzerland <ref>https://www.zh.ch/internet/de/ktzh/kunstsammlung/kuenstler.html Kunstsammlung des Kanton Zuerich. Retrieved on 9 Dec. 2017.</ref>

Zimmermann, Palgrave Macmillan, New York 2015. {{ISBN|978-1-137-43361-9}} (hardcover), {{ISBN|978-1-137-43362-6}} (paperback). * Ostrale'13 – We Cross the Rubicon, exhibition catalogue, Dresden, 2013. * Images Against Darkness. Video art from the archive of imai – inter media art institute, KIT Kunst im Tunnel, Düsseldorf, 2012. * Myriam Thyes – Glasgow Styles / Magnify Malta, by Kunstverein Duisburg, Kehrer Artbooks, Heidelberg, 2012, {{ISBN|978-3-86828-276-4}} <ref>http://opac.nebis.ch/F/64EMALUNKNEBSU9XP5SKTBTEK5DGFAKC1GPIVXNNSI9U396JAB-00429?func=full-set-set&set_number=018971&set_entry=000001&format=999</ref> * Connect – Art Between Media and Reality, Swiss Federal Office of Culture + Shedhalle Zurich, Verlag fuer Moderne Kunst, Nuremberg, 2011, {{ISBN|978-3-86984-246-2}} <ref>http://www.digicult.it/news/connect-art-between-media-and-reality/</ref> * Pixels and Places – Video Art in Public Space, by Catrien Schreuder, NAi Publishers, Rotterdam, 2010, {{ISBN|978-90-5662-738-6}}. * Re-Imagining Animation, by Paul Wells + Johnny Hardstaff (UK), AVA Academia publishing, Lausanne, Thames & Hudson, 2008, {{ISBN|978-2-940373-69-7}}. * Nothing to declare. 4th Triennial of Contemporary Art Oberschwaben, exhibition catalog, Verlag für moderne Kunst Nuremberg, 2008. * Myriam Thyes – UmBildungen/ReVisions, monograph, by [[Imai – inter media art institute]], Kehrer Artbooks, Heidelberg, 2007, {{ISBN|978-3-939583-46-2}}<ref>http://opac.nebis.ch/F/64EMALUNKNEBSU9XP5SKTBTEK5DGFAKC1GPIVXNNSI9U396JAB-00432?func=full-set-set&set_number=018971&set_entry=000002&format=999</ref> * German Video Art 2002-2004, Marl Media Art Prizes, Skulpturenmuseum Glaskasten, Marl, 2004.<ref>Deutsche Video-Kunst 2002-2004, {{ISBN|3-924790-69-8}}</ref> * Treibhaus 6, Museum Kunstpalast, Düsseldorf, 1994. * Connect. revision.text:
The '''National Border Targeting Centre''' (NBTC) is a division and site of the [[Border Force]] in the UK, that collates and processes data from people entering and leaving the UK. It is the information-processing site that keeps track of migration into the UK. It operates 24 hours a day.
==History== It was opened on Thursday 11 March 2010 by the [[UK Border Agency]] (UKBA). The e-Borders systems had been launched in May 2009, with Project Semaphore running as a prototype from 2004.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/technology/3700232.stm Project Semaphore]</ref> It replaced the Joint Border Operations Centre (JBOC) at Heathrow, a much smaller site.<ref>[http://icinspector.independent.gov.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/10/An-Inspection-of-eborders.pdf Report]</ref>
==Structure== The site is run by the [[Home Office]]. It has around 200 staff in [[Wythenshawe]], Manchester.<ref>[https://www.gov.uk/government/news/e-borders-snares-2-800-criminals-at-the-border Visit in April 2011]</ref> It is part of the Intelligence, Targeting and Watchlisting Command within the Border Force.
==Function== Passengers on flights [[Border control|entering and leaving]] the UK are screened by the NBTC.<ref>[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-3374999/Almost-300-suspected-terrorists-criminals-illegal-migrants-trying-cross-UK-border-DAY.html Daily Mail December 2015]</ref> The airlines pass data ([[passenger name record]], or PNR) of each passenger to the NBTC, including date of birth. The NBTC tracks former flights taken by each individual going back up to a decade, and determines whether an individual's flight history could be suspicious. Each individual is checked against criminal record databases. Exit checks are conducted at Ferry Ports connecting to European Ports by the ferry operators.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.doverport.co.uk/about/news/introduction-of-government-imposed-exit-checks-at/12953/|title=- Port of Dover|website=www.doverport.co.uk|access-date=2018-04-14}}</ref>
It looks at the [[e-Borders]] Semaphore system for suspects. It looks mainly for rapists and murderers and pirates. It tracks around 250 million passenger movements per year. It has no defence against false [[passport]]s. It operates the Pre-Departure Checks Scheme.
==See also== * [[Office of Biometric Identity Management]] * Centaur, the information database held by [[HM Revenue and Customs|HMRC]] * [[UK Visas and Immigration]], partly headquartered in central Liverpool
==References== {{reflist}}
{{UK Border Force}} {{Borders of the United Kingdom}} {{Home Office (United Kingdom)}} {{Manchester}}
[[Category:2010 establishments in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Borders of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Criminal records]] [[Category:Government agencies established in 2010]] [[Category:Government buildings completed in 2010]] [[Category:Government databases in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Law enforcement databases]] [[Category:Office buildings in Manchester]] [[Category:Travel technology]] [[Category:United Kingdom border control]] [[Category:Wythenshawe]]
